title: What subtle errors have you found in books? - Quora

response.answer_text: Question: What subtle errors have you found in books? Here we go another opportunity to bash the Jack Reacher series of novels. Let’s see: Jack Reacher rides across the country on buses - The major bus lines only stop in cities larger than 50k, unless there’s a military installation, a Native American reservation or a very popular tourist destination nearby. They no longer stop in small towns and they haven’t for some time. Even the private bus lines only travel between major cities or to specific destinations like casinos or resorts.Jack Reacher buys clothes from secondhand or discount stores - The character is described to be a hulking man of six feet five inches in height. Not only would he have difficulty finding clothing in secondhand stores, he would do in many regular departments of which there are not very many (besides Wal*Mart) in too many places throughout much of the United States.Reacher stays at small, out of the way, motels - The author has clearly never stayed in those types of places in the United States, as most are very dangerous locations even in the best of times. The majority have seen far better days and now mainly house people who are one step above homelessness, transient workers, and people who make their living committing some sort of criminal offenses.It’s clear that while the author may currently live in the United States (New York City to be exact) that he did most of his “research” using an atlas and by reading newspaper articles. Here’s one that escaped me for many years until I became an adult: Don Pendleton’s Mack Bolan- The Executioner series of novels frequently had the character using particular rifles for long distance shooting. Those included a .44 Magnum lever action and a .45–70 Government model. Neither weapon is particularly good for distance shooting ( I own a .45–70) and any knowledgeable shooter would have used something much different. It’s clear that while Pendleton (when he was alive) could write gripping narratives, he was less successful when it came to identifying the correct “tools for the job”.

My all time favorite is from John Baxter’s The Black Yacht (1982), a thriller set in the world of high-stakes sailboat racing (now there’s a niche genre!). At one point a character is on the water with a small, one-person high-performance sailboat called a Laser. He is, for reasons I’ve long since forgotten, trying to be stealthy and inconspicuous, so he has the boat floating on its side (as if he’s capsized) and is treading water alongside it. The moment at which he wants to take action comes, so he flips the boat upright, hoists the sail, and . . . Um . . . no. One of the quirks of the Laser is that the sail has a sleeve sewn into the leading edge, into which you slide the mast before setting the base of the mast into a socket molded into the deck of the boat. There’s literally no way to raise (or lower) the sail on a Laser without shipping (or unshipping) the entire mast, something that’s impossible to do if you and the boat are at sea. This is my gold standard for “subtle error:” It looks completely normal to 99.99% of readers, but that to the other 0.01%—in this case, those who have actually sailed a Laser—it’s as jarring as a red ace of spades.  Honorable Mention: The scene in The Runaway Jury where John Grisham has two characters sitting at the counter at a Waffle House restaurant [a chain so ubiquitous in the American South that its unofficial slogan could be: “If you can’t find one, you deserve to starve”], and scarfing down pancakes. Waffle House offers (nearly) every classic American combination of fat, salt, and carbohydrates that a hungry diner might want for breakfast. They do things with hash browns that nature never imagined. You can get (almost) anything in the diner-food universe that you want there. There is, however, one exception. They don’t serve pancakes There are currently 77 Waffle House locations in the State of Mississippi, to which Grisham’s family moved when he was four. That he could have reached adulthood believing in some bizarre alternate universe filled with pancake-peddling Waffle Houses beggars belief. And yet . . . But never mind: The Runaway Jury is, inexplicable pancakes notwithstanding, my favorite Grisham novel. Also: I’m now irrationally hungry for a plate-sized pecan waffle doused in cheap maple syrup.
